newsitem.title: USA: Stocks mixed; weigh earnings data.
newsitem.headline: Stocks mixed; weigh earnings data.

text.p: Stocks were mixed Thursday as the market consolidated while focusing on corporate earnings reports.
At 1 p.m. EDT/1700 GMT, the Dow was up 13.12 points at 7,855.55.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines 14-11 on active volume of 310 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq composite index slipped 2.01 points to 1,484.62.
Analysts said stocks reached such high levels that they were the target of profit-taking in the absence of fresh economic data.
Earnings results set the direction of individual stocks, as investors rotated among sectors.
"The market is edgy," said Dick Stein, vice president of U.S. Clearing Corp. "There are a lot of people out there with nice, big profits who are quick to pull the trigger."
The 30-year Treasury bond was off 5/32, or $1.56 on a $1,000 bond, which lifted its yield to 6.58 percent from 6.56 percent Wednesday. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.

"Valuations have gotten so high that we need really positive news to get people buying aggressively," said Roy Blumberg, chief investment strategist at Josephthal Lyon & Ross. "A backup in bonds and some nervous after the stock market's recent volatility is enough to send shares lower."
Investors were busily rotating among groups, using earnings results and valuations to guide their actions, traders said.
Technology stocks lost steam after some below-forecast earnings reports, they said.

"Nasdaq has been closing at new record highs every day, so it is subject to profit-taking as the earnings come out," said Jim Benning, a trader at BT Brokerage. "It's a question of stock selection here."
Intel Corp., a recent gainer, shed 1-7/8 to 150-3/4 in active trade, setting a softer tone for the broader technology market.
Compaq Computer Corp. also weakened 1-1/8 to 120, after the company reported quarterly earnings that were above analysts' expectations but stood below the so-called "whisper" estimate.
The "whisper" number refers to unpublished earnings estimates that circulate on Wall Street ahead of earnings.
"The market cannot tolerate anything but really fantastic news," said James Melcher, president of Balestra Capital.
Kmart Corp. lost 3/4 to 10-3/4. The retailer said markdowns in its women's apparel business would keep its second-quarter net income below its year-ago profit levels.
